summary: This document contains a detailed timeline of events surrounding the suicide of Jeffrey Epstein on August 10, 2019, at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) New York, and a subsequent memorandum from the Bureau of Prisons (BOP) Reentry Services Division providing feedback on the institution's response to a psychological reconstruction of the suicide. It reveals procedural issues, lack of documentation, and institutional biases. This document is a collection of email correspondence and attachments from the Federal Bureau of Prisons. The primary content is a memorandum from the Reentry Services Division providing feedback on MCC New York's response to a psychological reconstruction report regarding the suicide of inmate Jeffrey Epstein. It details numerous institutional issues and corrective actions. The document also includes a forwarded Google Alert about Epstein's death and an email chain concerning inmate complaints and attorney access issues for another inmate. This document is a collection of email correspondence primarily concerning inmate conditions and legal access at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) in New York. It includes discussions about moving inmate Nicholas Tartaglione, difficulties his defense team faced in visiting him and providing discovery, and a forwarded news article about Jeffrey Epstein's suicide. A later email discusses Bureau of Prisons (BOP) policy regarding program evaluations. This document contains email correspondence from August 2019 regarding a scheduled tour of the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) New York by Department of Justice officials following Jeffrey Epstein's death, and separate email threads concerning attorney access to inmate Nicholas Tartaglione. It reveals planned official access to Epstein's cell and details systemic issues with legal visitation at the MCC. This document is an email chain between defense attorney Bruce Barket and Bureau of Prisons/legal staff regarding the detention conditions and legal access difficulties faced by inmate Nick Tartaglione at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) in New York. Barket details severe issues including long delays for attorney visits, loss of legal materials, poor cell conditions, and lack of access to books and recreation, arguing these conditions impede Tartaglione's ability to prepare for his death penalty trial. This document is an email chain from July 2019 between defense attorney Bruce Barket and federal prosecutors regarding severe difficulties in accessing and representing his client, Nicholas Tartaglione, at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC). Barket details systemic issues including excessive delays for legal visits, poor prison conditions, loss of legal materials, and inadequate access to discovery, arguing these conditions impair Tartaglione's defense in his death penalty case. This document is a series of email exchanges from July 2019 between defense attorney Bruce Barket and a Supervisory Staff Attorney at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) regarding the detention conditions and legal access difficulties of inmate Nick Tartaglione. The emails detail complaints about inhumane conditions in the SHU, systemic delays in attorney visits, and issues with accessing legal materials, all while Tartaglione is facing a death penalty case. This document is a series of email correspondences primarily between defense attorney Bruce Barket and officials at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) regarding the detention conditions and legal access of inmate Nicholas Tartaglione. It details complaints about prolonged visitation delays, lack of access to legal materials, poor cell conditions, and a request for psychiatric medication. A separate email chain shows an out-of-office notification related to Jeffrey Epstein's case. This document is an email chain from July 2019 between defense attorney Bruce Barket and a Supervisory Staff Attorney at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) concerning the harsh conditions and restricted legal access for inmate Nick Tartaglione. It details complaints about leaking cells, lack of reading materials, lost legal discovery, and systemic delays in attorney visits, which the defense argues impedes their ability to prepare for a death penalty case. This is a Washington Post newsletter article (The Daily 202) analyzing the second night of the second 2020 Democratic presidential primary debate held in Detroit on July 31, 2019. It focuses on Joe Biden's aggressive debate strategy, his attacks on rivals, and media reactions to the event. The document also includes brief news summaries on other topics like U.S.-Iran tensions and Federal Reserve policy. This document is an email from The Washington Post containing a newsletter (The Daily 202) with political commentary about a 2019 Democratic debate, along with technical metadata about the email's storage and archival. It appears to be part of a collection of electronic records, but contains no substantive information related to the Epstein case. This document is an email newsletter from The Washington Post's 'The Daily 202' dated August 1, 2019. It primarily covers analysis of the second 2020 Democratic presidential primary debate held in Detroit, focusing on Joe Biden's performance and attacks from other candidates. A significant portion of the newsletter also covers other political news, and it concludes with a brief section mentioning Jeffrey Epstein's alleged plan to seed the human race with his DNA and his past social relationship with Donald Trump. This document is an email chain from the Bureau of Prisons (BOP) discussing a reporter's inquiry about rising federal prison suicides, referencing Jeffrey Epstein's death. It includes BOP's response detailing suicide prevention training and data, and contains attachments with suicide statistics from 2014-2018 and 1990-2019. This document is a data table extracted from an Excel file titled 'Mail Attachment Annual Data Summary 1990-2019.xlsx'. It presents annual counts for three categories ('Count of Attempts', 'Count of Self Harm', 'Count of Suicide Watch') across numerous three-letter facility codes from 2014 to 2019. The data appears to be institutional statistics, likely from a prison or detention system, and is part of a larger document set in the Epstein case files. This document is a Bureau of Prisons record containing a 'Psych Observation' log for Jeffrey Epstein from July 8-10, 2019, while he was on suicide watch/psych observation at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC). It includes a detailed, handwritten log of his behavior and condition during this period, as well as metadata showing the email transmission of this record between BOP staff. This document is a collection of email correspondence and a suicide watch log from the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) in New York. It includes a suicide/psych observation log for an inmate (likely Jeffrey Epstein), emails from the Office of the Inspector General (OIG) requesting staff interviews regarding the 'incident last weekend' involving Epstein, and legal correspondence regarding attorney access and a site visit for another inmate, Tartaglione. The emails reveal internal prison communications and coordination with investigators following Epstein's incarceration. This document contains email correspondence from July 7, 2019, regarding attorney Martin Weinberg's difficulty accessing his client Jeffrey Epstein at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) following Epstein's arrest. It also includes a later email from August 12, 2019, transmitting a 'Suicide Watch Chronological Log' for Jeffrey Epstein dated July 23-24, 2019, which details observations of him on suicide watch. This document is a newsletter from The Washington Post's 'The Daily 202' dated July 11, 2019. It discusses the political 'era of no regrets,' focusing on Labor Secretary Alexander Acosta's defense of his 2008 plea deal with Jeffrey Epstein and Speaker Nancy Pelosi's refusal to apologize for her comments about progressive freshmen congresswomen. It also covers various other political news items from the time. This document is a compilation of news articles from a larger file, covering a wide range of political and legal topics from mid-2019. It includes updates on immigration policy, Puerto Rico corruption arrests, military nominations, the 2020 election, emoluments lawsuits, and international diplomacy. A brief mention of Jeffrey Epstein appears at the very end, referencing a new accuser. This document is a newsletter from The Washington Post (The Daily 202) dated July 11, 2019, summarizing multiple news reports related to Jeffrey Epstein. It covers allegations of sexual abuse by a victim, scrutiny of Manhattan DA Cyrus Vance Jr.'s handling of Epstein's sex offender status, Labor Secretary Alexander Acosta's proposed budget cuts affecting anti-trafficking efforts, questions about Epstein's wealth and connections, and his property in the Virgin Islands. This is an email chain from October 22, 2019, regarding a media inquiry from USA Today about monitoring video of suicide-risk inmates in segregated housing. A Bureau of Prisons (BOP) official clarifies the question is not about suicide watch and should be referred to the Correctional Programs Division (CPD). The email includes internal discussion about drafting a response, referencing procedures for inmates in specialized mental health units. This document is an internal email chain from the Bureau of Prisons (BOP) Public Information Office regarding a media inquiry from USA Today reporter Kevin Johnson. The inquiry asks about new procedures for monitoring surveillance video of inmates at risk for suicide following Jeffrey Epstein's death. The emails contain a drafted response detailing BOP's standard suicide prevention protocols and internal discussions about how to answer the reporter. This document contains email correspondence from December 2019 regarding a request by defense attorneys to view the cells and common areas where inmate Nicholas Tartaglione was held at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) in New York. The emails involve discussions between a U.S. Attorney's Office civil division chief, a supervisory staff attorney at the MCC, and others about scheduling a site visit for the defense team. The document also includes a Google Alerts email summary from January 2020 containing news articles about the Bureau of Prisons, including one referencing Jeffrey Epstein's cell. This document is a compilation of news articles from The Washington Post's 'Power Up' newsletter, covering topics including political reactions to Trump's 'send her back' rally, preparations for Robert Mueller's congressional testimony, an interview with Al Franken, and new allegations about Jeffrey Epstein's continued travel with underage girls after his conviction. The document appears to be part of a larger set of case files, with the Epstein section being the most relevant. This document is an email newsletter from The Washington Post titled 'The Daily 202', dated July 22, 2019. It contains a collection of news briefs covering various international and domestic topics, including the Ebola epidemic, U.S.-Venezuela tensions, and U.S. political figures. It appears as an archived email within a larger document set related to the Epstein case, but its direct connection to the case is not evident from this text chunk. This document contains a December 27, 2019, memorandum from the Federal Bureau of Prisons Reentry Services Division providing feedback on MCC New York's response to the psychological reconstruction of Jeffrey Epstein's suicide. It critiques the institution's corrective actions and highlights issues like unclear documentation, staff bias, and lack of psychologist input in housing decisions. The document also includes attached emails and a detailed timeline of events surrounding Epstein's death on August 10, 2019. This document contains a detailed minute-by-minute timeline of events surrounding the death of Jeffrey Epstein at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) New York on August 10, 2019, from the day before through subsequent investigations. It also includes internal email correspondence and a forwarded news article about the medical examiner's ruling. This document contains email correspondence and news clips from 2019-2020 related to the Bureau of Prisons and the Jeffrey Epstein case. It includes an out-of-office message from a prison official, news articles about Epstein's missing surveillance video and other prison matters, and an email thread regarding a defense attorney's request to view a client's cell at the Metropolitan Correctional Center. This document is a collection of email threads and internal records from the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) New York, primarily concerning the death of Jeffrey Epstein and a separate legal matter for inmate Tartaglione. It includes a detailed timeline of Epstein's death, internal communications about suicide watch, and a request from an attorney to view a client's cell. This document contains multiple email threads and a memorandum related to the Jeffrey Epstein case. It includes a memo scheduling a DOJ tour of the Metropolitan Correctional Center after Epstein's death, emails referencing news about erased footage from outside Epstein's cell, a GovExec newsletter mentioning Alex Acosta's involvement in the Epstein scandal, and a Google Alert about the Bureau of Prisons. The content shows internal communications and external news monitoring related to the case. This document contains email correspondence from July 2019 between defense attorney Bruce Barket and Bureau of Prisons staff regarding the detention conditions and legal access for inmate Nicholas Tartaglione at the Metropolitan Correctional Center in New York. It details complaints about poor conditions, visitation delays, and lack of access to legal materials. This document is an email chain from July 2019 between defense attorney Bruce Barket and staff at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) regarding the detention conditions and legal access for his client, Nicholas Tartaglione. Barket details severe issues including water leaks, a dead rodent in the cell, lack of reading material and discovery, and systemic delays in attorney visits, arguing these conditions are hindering Tartaglione's defense in a death penalty case. This document is an email chain from July 2019 concerning the detention conditions and legal access issues of inmate Nicholas Tartaglione at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) in New York. Defense attorney Bruce Barket complains about severe delays in attorney visits, poor cell conditions (leaks, pests, lighting), and denial of access to discovery materials and books. A Supervisory Staff Attorney and an Assistant U.S. Attorney respond, outlining steps being taken to address the complaints. This document is an email chain from July 2019 between defense attorney Bruce Barket and a Supervisory Staff Attorney at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) concerning the conditions of confinement and access issues for their client, inmate Nicholas Tartaglione. Barket details severe delays in legal visits, loss of legal materials, and poor conditions in the SHU, including a leak, pest infestation, and lack of recreation. The MCC staff attorney responds with efforts to address the complaints. This document is a series of forwarded email chains from July 2019 concerning the detention conditions and legal access of inmate Nicholas Tartaglione at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) in New York. The emails are between defense attorney Bruce Barket, a Supervisory Staff Attorney at MCC, an Assistant United States Attorney, and a Chief Psychologist, detailing complaints about leaks, pests, lack of discovery, and difficulties in attorney-client meetings. This document is a chain of emails from July 2019 between defense attorney Bruce Barket and various Bureau of Prisons (BOP) and U.S. Attorney's Office staff regarding the harsh detention conditions and severe access issues faced by his client, Nicholas Tartaglione, at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) in New York. The emails detail systemic problems including long delays for legal visits, lack of access to discovery materials, poor cell conditions (water leaks, dead rodents), and concerns about Tartaglione's deteriorating mental health while facing the death penalty. This document is an email chain from July 2019, primarily featuring attorney Bruce Barket complaining to prison officials and prosecutors about the harsh conditions and restricted legal access for his client, Nick Tartaglione, who is being held in the SHU at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) in New York. The emails detail systemic delays in attorney visits, loss of legal materials, poor cell conditions, and concerns about Tartaglione's mental health while facing the death penalty. This document is a news article compilation from 'The Daily 202' briefing, covering multiple topics including polling data on Republican views on immigration, Trump administration immigration policies, allegations against opera singer Placido Domingo, changes to the Endangered Species Act, and climate change data. It contains no direct information related to the Epstein case. This document is a page from The Washington Post's 'The Daily 202' newsletter dated August 13, 2019. It covers multiple news stories, with significant focus on Attorney General Bill Barr's comments on the 'failure' at the Metropolitan Correctional Center following Jeffrey Epstein's death, and an op-ed from James Stewart about Epstein claiming to have damaging information on powerful people. The newsletter also covers other topics including the opioid crisis, Hong Kong protests, and 2020 presidential campaign updates. This document contains metadata for an email from The Washington Post, scheduled for delivery on August 13, 2019, with the subject "The Daily 202: New poll identifies fault lines inside the GOP over Trump's immigration agenda and treatment of asylum seekers." It includes technical details about the message, attachments, and audit trail, but no substantive content related to the Epstein case is present in the provided text. This document is primarily a forwarded email newsletter from The Washington Post dated August 13, 2019, containing political news summaries on immigration, the Epstein case, and other topics. Appended to the end is a brief email chain between legal professionals (likely Epstein's defense team) from August 30, 2019, scheduling a call to discuss conditions at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC). This document contains email correspondence between attorneys and federal officials regarding conditions of confinement and legal visit access for inmate Nicholas Tartaglione at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) in New York. It includes complaints about inadequate conditions, requests for site visits, and scheduling discussions among legal teams. This document contains internal Bureau of Prisons email correspondence regarding the suicide watch and death of Jeffrey Epstein. It includes a detailed timeline of his death, suicide watch logs, and communications about a medical mortality review and psychological reconstruction. The emails reveal procedural issues, such as the use of the wrong logbook for suicide watch. This document is a collection of Bureau of Prisons suicide watch logs and related email correspondence for inmate Jeffrey Edward Epstein from July 23-24, 2019, at the Metropolitan Correctional Center in New York. It includes observation logs and an inmate history report showing his placement on suicide watch. This document contains email correspondence from late 2019 regarding a request by attorneys for inmate Nicholas Tartaglione to view his jail cell at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) in preparation for a potential penalty phase. It also includes a forwarded promotional email from the Poynter Institute discussing jail suicides in light of Jeffrey Epstein's death, and a separate email thread about a media inquiry from USA Today regarding video monitoring. This document is an internal email chain from the Bureau of Prisons (BOP) Public Information Office discussing a media inquiry from USA Today reporter Kevin Johnson. The inquiry asks about new measures to monitor surveillance video in segregated housing units for inmates at risk of suicide following Jeffrey Epstein's death. The emails show BOP staff drafting, editing, and seeking approval for a response, clarifying policies on suicide watch versus camera monitoring, and referring the matter to the Correctional Programs Division (CPD). This document is an email chain from the Bureau of Prisons (BOP) Public Information Office discussing a media inquiry from USA Today reporter Kevin Johnson regarding suicide monitoring practices following Jeffrey Epstein's death. It includes proposed responses, internal edits, and background on BOP suicide prevention protocols. This document contains two main parts: 1) An email chain from August 12, 2019, regarding a procedural error in the suicide watch log for inmate Jeffrey Epstein on July 23-24, 2019, where the wrong logbook was initially used. 2) An email from September 3, 2019, discussing a court hearing in the Bistrian v. USA case where Judge Cynthia Rufe referenced the public and Attorney General's outrage over Jeffrey Epstein's suicide watch, drawing a parallel to the case at hand. This is an email metadata record showing a message with the subject 'Bistrun Update & USAO Meeting Request for Wednesday Sept 4th' sent on September 3, 2019. It appears to be a communication regarding an update and a meeting request with the U.S. Attorney's Office (USAO), likely related to the Epstein case.

Both are included in the same email chain discussing legal strategy regarding MCC conditions.
Both are attorneys copied on case-related emails.
Berman's office was planning to visit MCC, including areas related to Tartaglione's confinement.
The Associate Warden was responsible for overseeing procedures and communications related to inmate Epstein's custody, suicide watch, and death.
Adam is a staff member assigned to observe and log Epstein's behavior every 15 minutes while Epstein is on suicide watch.
Long is the BOP Public Information Officer responsible for drafting and sending an official response to Johnson's media inquiry.
Long references Sue Allison, the Deputy AD of IPPA, as being involved in the review process for the media response.
Long is seeking review and input from Michelle, a staff member likely in the Correctional Programs Division (CPD), for the draft response.
An Assistant Director (AD) provided direct guidance to Long, advising against using a prior draft and directing the inquiry to CPD.
Long is the BOP Public Information Officer responding to Johnson's media inquiry about suicide monitoring practices.
RSD helped Long draft an earlier media response about BOP suicide prevention practices.
Long consults with Michelle on how to respond to the USA Today reporter's inquiry.
Adam was a staff observer documenting Epstein's status on suicide watch on July 23-24, 2019.
Judge Rufe referenced Epstein's suicide watch and the subsequent firing of a warden as a public example of accountability during a hearing in an unrelated case.
Judge Rufe addressed Attorney Kaufman directly during oral arguments, expressing frustration with the Department of Justice's handling of evidence.
Judge Rufe's comments prompted Attorney Bazelon to agree and seek further investigation into a prior incident.
Aaron Taylor assaulted inmate Bistrian in October 2006, which is the subject of the civil lawsuit.
Jezior was a witness who testified in the trial of Kareem Milhouse.

events.title: Epstein's Last Full Day
events.description: Epstein's cellmate, Efrain Reyes, departs for court and does not return. Epstein spends the day in attorney conferences and is reported to be in good spirits during a social call in the evening.

events.title: Epstein Found Unresponsive and Dies
events.description: Epstein is found unresponsive in his cell at 6:33 am. CPR and medical intervention are performed, but he is pronounced dead at Beekman Hospital at 7:36 am. Multiple agencies (FBI, OIG, USMS) are notified and respond.

events.title: BOP Feedback Memorandum
events.description: The Assistant Director of the BOP Reentry Services Division sends a memorandum to the Northeast Regional Director, critiquing MCC New York's response to the psychological reconstruction of Epstein's suicide, citing unclear corrective actions and institutional biases.

events.title: Epstein Incident in MCC
events.description: An incident involving Jeffrey Epstein where it was unclear if he engaged in self-directed violence or was assaulted. An incident report was written presuming self-directed violence before the SIS investigation concluded.

events.title: Epstein's Death and BOP Director Removal
events.description: Google Alert references the death of Jeffrey Epstein and the subsequent removal of the acting director of the Federal Bureau of Prisons by Attorney General Barr.

events.title: Institution Response to Psychological Reconstruction
events.description: MCC New York submitted a response to a Psychological Reconstruction report concerning the suicide of Jeffrey Epstein.

events.title: Complaints about Tartaglione's Conditions
events.description: Bruce Barket emails the MCC Supervisory Staff Attorney detailing extensive problems with visiting his client Nicholas Tartaglione, delays in receiving discovery, and harsh conditions in SHU.

events.title: Epstein Attorney Access Verified
events.description: An email chain confirms that Martin Weinberg's attorney credentials were verified for visiting Jeffrey Epstein at MCC after his arrest.

events.title: Jeffrey Epstein's Suicide
events.description: A forwarded news article reports that Jeffrey Epstein committed suicide in his cell at the Metropolitan Correctional Center.

events.title: News Article Compilation
events.description: An email is sent containing links to various news articles, including one about Epstein's suicide and union pushback, and another about an inmate suicide in Miami.

events.title: BOP Program Evaluation Discussion
events.description: Internal BOP email discusses prioritizing the creation of a clearinghouse process for evaluating faith-based and other programs, prompted by Director Sawyer's Senate testimony.

events.title: DOJ/USAO Tour of MCC NY
events.description: Scheduled tour for representatives of the Department of Justice and the SDNY USAO of the Special Housing Unit (SHU), inmate Jeffrey Epstein's cell, and the suicide watch area at the Metropolitan Correctional Center, New York.

events.title: Attorney Bruce Barket's Delayed Visit
events.description: Bruce Barket arrived at MCC at 7:56 AM to visit client Nicholas Tartaglione but experienced significant delays, not seeing his client until after 9:00 AM, cutting the visit short due to inmate count procedures.

events.title: Discussion on Tartaglione's Conditions and Discovery
events.description: Email exchange between Bruce Barket and an AUSA regarding delays in loading discovery onto a hard drive for Tartaglione and a denied request to transfer Tartaglione to Nassau County.

events.title: Barket and Leisenring Visit Tartaglione
events.description: Bruce Barket and Aida Leisenring visited Nick Tartaglione at MCC. They arrived at 7:55 AM but had to wait over an hour; Tartaglione was not brought to them until almost 9:30 AM, resulting in only a 20-30 minute meeting.

events.title: Sunday Visit Attempt with Long Delay
events.description: Bruce Barket arrived for a Sunday visit at 7:56 AM but was forced to wait outside for 35 minutes due to staffing issues. He did not get to see his client until after 9:00 AM.

events.title: Barket's Evening Visit with Tartaglione
events.description: Bruce Barket was able to visit Nick Tartaglione in the evening, arranged by a staff member. During this visit, Tartaglione reported finding a dead rodent in his bed and that his mental health was deteriorating rapidly.

events.title: Email Chain on Conditions and Visits
events.description: A series of emails begins between Bruce Barket and BOP/AUSA staff, detailing ongoing problems with visitation delays, loss of legal materials, and poor conditions in the SHU for Nick Tartaglione.

events.title: Barket's Sunday Visit Complaint
events.description: Bruce Barket arrives at MCC at 7:56 AM but is forced to wait over an hour outside, finally seeing his client Nicholas Tartaglione just after 9:00 AM, leaving less than 30 minutes before the mandatory 9:30 AM cutoff.

events.title: Previous Visit Delay
events.description: Barket and Leisenring arrive at MCC at 7:55 AM but are not permitted to see Tartaglione until 9:30 AM, resulting in another severely shortened legal visit.

events.title: Prosecutor Response on Conditions
events.description: A Supervisory Staff Attorney at MCC responds to Barket's complaints, outlining steps taken to address Tartaglione's access to books, legal work, recreation, and the law library.

events.title: Barket's Visit and Condition Report
events.description: Bruce Barket visits Nick Tartaglione at MCC and reports ongoing deplorable conditions: water leaks, a dead rodent in the bed, lights malfunctioning, and Tartaglione's rapidly diminishing mental health. Tartaglione also reports being told of severe sanctions (denied visits, phone, commissary for a year).

events.title: Sunday Visit Delays
events.description: Bruce Barket arrives for a Sunday visit and experiences significant delays, waiting over an hour to see his client for less than 30 minutes due to staffing and procedural issues at the MCC.

events.title: Discovery and Transfer Request Denied
events.description: The Assistant U.S. Attorney informs the defense that the Marshals have refused the request to transfer Tartaglione to Nassau County. Separate correspondence addresses a delay in Tartaglione receiving a discovery hard drive due to a misaddressed package.

events.title: SHU Lieutenant's Meeting with Tartaglione
events.description: The SHU Lieutenant meets with Tartaglione to discuss his personal property (books, legal work), recreation, and law library access, enforcing a policy limiting inmates to 5 books in their cell.

events.title: Attorney Visit with Delays
events.description: Bruce Barket and Aida Leisenring visit Tartaglione at MCC. They arrive at 7:55 AM but Tartaglione is not brought down until almost 9:30 AM, resulting in a very short visit.

events.title: Sunday Visit with Delays
events.description: Bruce Barket arrives at MCC at 7:56 AM but faces delays, finally seeing Tartaglione just after 9:00 AM, cutting the visit short due to a 10:00 AM count.

events.title: Request for Psychiatric Medication
events.description: Bruce Barket emails MCC officials requesting that Tartaglione be seen for psychiatric medication due to his rapidly diminishing mental health, depression, and anxiety.

events.title: Out of Office Notification
events.description: An email indicates an individual will be out of the office. The subject line references Jeffrey Epstein and an attached timeline.

events.title: Delayed Attorney Visit
events.description: Bruce Barket and Aida Leisenring arrive at MCC at 7:55 AM but wait over an hour to see client Nick Tartaglione, resulting in only a 20-30 minute meeting.

events.title: Discovery Hard Drive Delivery Issue
events.description: Defense team's hard drive delivery to the U.S. Attorney's office was delayed due to a misaddressed package, requiring interoffice rerouting.

events.title: Cell Phone Seizure & SHU Placement
events.description: Nick Tartaglione was placed in the Special Housing Unit (SHU) as punishment for possessing a cell phone, leading to the restrictive conditions described.

events.title: Dead Rodent Found in Cell
events.description: Tartaglione reported finding a dead rodent in his bed, which he accidentally smothered while sleeping, highlighting unsanitary conditions.

events.title: Second Night of Second Democratic Debate
events.description: 2020 Democratic presidential primary debate held in Detroit featuring Joe Biden, Kamala Harris, Cory Booker, and others. Characterized by Biden's aggressive counterattacks on rivals.

events.title: Federal Reserve Interest Rate Cut
events.description: The Fed cut the benchmark interest rate for the first time in over a decade by a quarter-point to just under 2.25%.

events.title: Sanctions on Iranian Foreign Minister
events.description: Trump administration imposed sanctions on Iranian Foreign Minister Mohammad Javad Zarif, escalating tensions.

events.title: Democratic Debate Coverage
events.description: The Washington Post's Daily 202 newsletter provides commentary and jokes from late-night hosts (Stephen Colbert, Samantha Bee, Jimmy Kimmel) about a Democratic presidential debate.

events.title: Email Sent
events.description: The Washington Post sent an email newsletter titled 'The Daily 202: Counterpunching Ike Trump, Raton attacked mast of his rival. on the debate stage. De looked weak' (subject appears garbled).

events.title: Trump-Epstein Rivalry Over Palm Beach Property
events.description: Donald Trump and Jeffrey Epstein became rivals over the rights to a Palm Beach, Florida, estate seized in the bankruptcy of Abe Gosman. Trump ultimately won the property.

events.title: Trump Provides Information on Epstein
events.description: Attorney Brad Edwards, representing some of Jeffrey Epstein's accusers, stated that Donald Trump was the only person among Epstein's acquaintances who agreed to talk and provide information when Edwards was investigating.

events.title: Reporter inquiry on federal prison suicides
events.description: A reporter sends questions to the BOP about rising federal prison suicides, specifically referencing Jeffrey Epstein's recent death, and requests historical data.

events.title: USA Today article on prison suicides
events.description: A USA Today article is published reporting that federal prison suicides were rising before Jeffrey Epstein's death, which prompts the reporter's inquiry to the BOP.

events.title: Epstein Placed on Psych Observation
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein is placed on a Psych Observation/Suicide Watch at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC). The observation log begins at 6 pm.

events.title: Psych Observation Ends
events.description: The formal Psych Observation for Jeffrey Epstein concludes at 9 am.

events.title: Psych Observation Record Emailed
events.description: The psych observation log from July 8-10 is compiled and emailed between BOP staff, with the email created and delivered on this date.

events.title: OIG Interview Requests
events.description: The Office of the Inspector General contacts MCC staff to request voluntary interviews regarding the 'incident last weekend' involving inmate Jeffrey Epstein.

events.title: Scheduled OIG Interview
events.description: A forensic psychologist schedules an interview with an OIG Special Agent for September 6, 2019, regarding the Epstein incident.

events.title: Attorney Access Verified
events.description: Prison staff verify attorney Martin Weinberg's credentials to ensure Jeffrey Epstein has access to counsel following his arrest.

events.title: Site Visit Request for Tartaglione
events.description: Defense attorney Bruce Barket requests to view the cells and common areas where his client, Tartaglione, has been held at MCC.

events.title: Arrest of Jeffrey Epstein
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein was arrested and detained at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC).

events.title: Attorney Access Issue at MCC
events.description: Attorney Martin Weinberg was denied access to meet with client Jeffrey Epstein at MCC due to being from out-of-state, prompting email correspondence to resolve the issue.

events.title: Scheduled Presentment on Indictment
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein was expected to be presented on an indictment following his arrest.

events.title: Epstein Placed on Suicide Watch
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein was placed on suicide watch at MCC, as documented in a chronological observation log.

events.title: Epstein Plea Deal
events.description: Labor Secretary Alexander Acosta, then a U.S. Attorney, negotiated a plea deal with Jeffrey Epstein that has been heavily criticized as lenient. A federal judge later ruled Acosta's office violated victims' rights by not notifying them.

events.title: Acosta News Conference
events.description: Labor Secretary Alexander Acosta held a news conference defending his role in the 2008 Epstein plea deal and declined to apologize to Epstein's victims.

events.title: Pelosi vs. 'The Squad'
events.description: Speaker Nancy Pelosi made dismissive comments about the influence of progressive freshman congresswomen ('the Squad'), leading to public tension and accusations of bullying.

events.title: McGrath Kavanaugh Flip-Flop
events.description: Kentucky Senate candidate Amy McGrath first said she would have probably voted to confirm Brett Kavanaugh, then hours later reversed her position and said she would have voted no.

events.title: Scheduled ICE Raids
events.description: ICE agents were preparing to arrest thousands of immigrants in raids scheduled to begin in at least 10 major cities, targeting those with deportation orders.

events.title: Carrizo Springs Shelter Opens
events.description: An emergency shelter for migrant children opened in Carrizo Springs, Texas, to alleviate cramped conditions in Border Patrol facilities.

events.title: ICE Notices to Immigrants
events.description: Many immigrants who had their proceedings expedited were given notice to report to ICE offices and leave the United States.

events.title: Trump's Fourth of July Event
events.description: President Trump's Fourth of July event in Washington D.C., along with surrounding protests, depleted the city's security fund.

events.title: Climate Change Testimony Blocked
events.description: State Department official Rod Schoonover testified before the House Intelligence Committee on climate change risks, but the White House blocked submission of his written statement.

events.title: Allegations Against Gen. John Hyten
events.description: A senior military officer accused Air Force Gen. John Hyten of sexual misconduct in 2017. An Air Force investigation found insufficient evidence.

events.title: 4th Circuit Dismisses Emoluments Case
events.description: A federal appeals court dismissed a lawsuit by Maryland and D.C. alleging Trump's D.C. hotel violated the Constitution's emoluments clauses, blocking discovery into his finances.

events.title: Kim Darroch Resignation
events.description: British Ambassador to the U.S. Kim Darroch resigned following criticism from President Trump over leaked diplomatic cables that were critical of the administration.

events.title: France Adopts Digital Tax
events.description: France adopted a 3% tax on revenue earned by major tech giants like Facebook and Google, prompting a U.S. investigation into potential discrimination.

events.title: New Accuser Against Jeffrey Epstein
events.description: A new accuser came forward alleging that Jeffrey Epstein raped her when she was 15 years old after recruiting her to work for him.

events.title: Araoz recruited by Epstein associate
events.description: A 14-year-old Araoz was approached outside her NYC high school by a young woman who began grooming her for Epstein.

events.title: Araoz alleges rape by Epstein
events.description: Araoz alleges Epstein forcibly raped her when she was 15 years old at his New York mansion.

events.title: Manhattan DA's office seeks lower sex offender status for Epstein
events.description: Prosecutor Jill Levin argued in court to reduce Epstein's sex offender classification to the lowest level.

events.title: Acosta proposes budget cuts to anti-trafficking agency
events.description: Labor Secretary Alexander Acosta's 2020 budget plan proposed an 80% cut to the International Labor Affairs Bureau, which fights child sex trafficking.

events.title: Alleged assault of Meredith Watson by Justin Fairfax
events.description: Meredith Watson alleges Justin Fairfax sexually assaulted her when they were undergraduates at Duke University.

events.title: Media Inquiry on Inmate Monitoring
events.description: USA Today submits a media inquiry regarding the monitoring via video of suicide-risk inmates in segregated housing. BOP officials internally discuss and draft a response.

events.title: Response to Washington Post on BOP Suicide Prevention
events.description: The BOP's IPPA leadership finalized and sent a detailed answer to the Washington Post regarding the Bureau's Suicide Prevention Program. This answer is reused as part of the draft response to USA Today.

events.title: USA Today Media Inquiry on Suicide Monitoring
events.description: Reporter Kevin Johnson submits an inquiry to the BOP asking if institutions are designating officers to monitor surveillance video in segregated housing for inmates at suicide risk, citing Epstein's death as the context.

events.title: BOP Staffing Snapshot
events.description: As of this date, the BOP had 15,012 working correctional officers and 1,654 vacant correctional officer positions, according to information included in a prior press response.

events.title: Defense Request for Cell Inspection
events.description: Attorney Bruce Barket emails a request to view the cells and common areas where his client Nicholas Tartaglione has been held at the MCC.

events.title: Follow-up on Site Visit Request
events.description: Email follow-up regarding the scheduling of a site visit for Tartaglione's defense team to inspect his housing conditions.

events.title: Scheduling Coordination
events.description: Further email correspondence coordinating schedules for the proposed site visit to the MCC for Tartaglione's defense.

events.title: Drug Smuggling Arrest at Beaumont Prison
events.description: News article summary about a Florida woman arrested for trying to smuggle drugs into the Federal Bureau of Prisons in Beaumont, Texas.

events.title: Trump's 'Send Her Back' Rally in Greenville
events.description: President Trump held a rally in Greenville, N.C., where the crowd chanted 'send her back' in reference to Rep. Ilhan Omar. The event divided the local community and was addressed by pastors in their sermons.

events.title: Mueller Testimony Before Congress
events.description: Former Special Counsel Robert Mueller is scheduled to testify before the House Judiciary and Intelligence Committees about his investigation into Russian interference and obstruction of justice.

events.title: Epstein's Post-Convict Travel with Underage Girls
events.description: A Vanity Fair investigation alleges Jeffrey Epstein continued to bring underage girls to his private island, St. James, on his private jets between January 2018 and June 2019, after his conviction and sex offender registration.

events.title: Palm Beach Sheriff's Office Internal Investigation
events.description: The Palm Beach County sheriff announced an internal affairs investigation into deputies assigned to monitor Jeffrey Epstein during his work release in 2008, where he was referred to as 'the client' and paid for security.

events.title: Al Franken's Resignation from Senate
events.description: Former Senator Al Franken resigned in December 2017 following multiple allegations of sexual misconduct. In a new interview, he expressed regret over his decision to resign.

events.title: Publication of The Daily 202 Newsletter
events.description: The Washington Post sent out its 'The Daily 202' email newsletter covering various news topics.

events.title: U.S.-Venezuela Aircraft Incident
events.description: A U.S. Navy EP-3 Aries II intelligence aircraft was 'aggressively shadowed' by a Venezuelan SU-30 Flanker fighter jet over the Caribbean Sea.

events.title: Iran Claims CIA Spy Detentions
events.description: Iran's intelligence ministry claimed it detained 17 citizens accused of acting as spies for the CIA and said some would be executed.

events.title: Kamala Harris Fundraiser Controversy
events.description: Taylor Swift fans criticized Senator Kamala Harris for holding a fundraiser at the home of music executive Scooter Braun.

events.title: Democratic Candidates Call for Puerto Rico Governor's Resignation
events.description: Several Democratic presidential candidates called on the governor of Puerto Rico to resign; Representative Tulsi Gabbard joined protesters.

events.title: Death of Jeffrey Epstein
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein was found unresponsive in his cell at MCC New York's Special Housing Unit at 6:33 am. CPR was initiated, EMS transported him to Beekman Hospital, and he was pronounced dead at 7:36 am.

events.title: Previous Incident Involving Epstein
events.description: An incident occurred where it was unclear if Epstein engaged in self-directed violence or was assaulted. An incident report was written presuming self-directed violence, which the memorandum criticizes as evidence of staff bias.

events.title: Epstein Found Unresponsive and Pronounced Dead
events.description: At 6:33 am, staff find Epstein unresponsive in his cell. CPR is initiated, EMS transports him to Beekman Hospital, and he is pronounced dead at 7:36 am by an ER physician.

events.title: Investigation and Notifications Begin
events.description: Multiple agencies are notified (FBI, OIG, AUSA), the next of kin (brother) is informed, the body is released for autopsy, and computer hard drives are removed from the SHU.

events.title: Medical Examiner Rules Suicide
events.description: The New York City medical examiner rules Jeffrey Epstein's death a suicide by hanging, as reported in a forwarded news article.

events.title: Out of Office Notification
events.description: A prison official sends an out-of-office message indicating they will be away August 12-16, 2019.

events.title: Epstein Jail Video Reported Missing
events.description: Prosecutors report that video surveillance footage from the time of Jeffrey Epstein's first suicide attempt in July is missing.

events.title: Manafort Charges Dismissed
events.description: New York Judge Maxwell Wiley dismisses state fraud charges against Paul Manafort on double-jeopardy grounds.

events.title: Ebbers Granted Compassionate Release
events.description: Federal judge Valerie Caproni grants compassionate release to former WorldCom CEO Bernard Ebbers.

events.title: Request to View Tartaglione Cell
events.description: Defense attorney Bruce Barket requests to view his client's cell and common areas at the Metropolitan Correctional Center.

events.title: News Article on Erased Epstein Footage
events.description: A news article is forwarded stating prosecutors say footage outside Epstein's cell during his suicide attempt was erased.

events.title: Request for Psych Observation Book
events.description: An email is sent to Chief Psychologist Darlene requesting Epstein's psych observation book, indicating monitoring of his mental state.

events.title: DAG/USAO Tour of SHU
events.description: Representatives from the Deputy Attorney General's Office and the U.S. Attorney's Office schedule a tour of the SHU, Epstein's cell, and the suicide watch area.

events.title: Tartaglione Cell Visit Request
events.description: Attorney Bruce Barket requests to view his client Tartaglione's cell. MCC staff and prosecutors coordinate schedules for the visit.

events.title: DOJ Tour of Metropolitan Correctional Center
events.description: A tour for representatives of the Department of Justice and the SDNY USAO is scheduled to take place at the Metropolitan Correctional Center in New York.

events.title: News about erased Epstein cell footage
events.description: News articles report that footage outside Jeffrey Epstein's cell during his suicide attempt was erased, according to prosecutors.

events.title: GovExec Today newsletter published
events.description: A newsletter includes a viewpoint article about Alex Acosta's legacy being embroiled in the Jeffrey Epstein scandal.

events.title: Email about Tartaglione conditions
events.description: Bruce Barket emails BOP staff about ongoing poor conditions for Nicholas Tartaglione at MCC, including visitation delays and lack of legal materials.

events.title: Failed Sunday visit attempt
events.description: Bruce Barket arrives at MCC to visit Tartaglione but experiences significant delays, waiting 35 minutes outside and only getting 30 minutes with client.

events.title: Discovery delivery issues
events.description: Communication about delays in Tartaglione receiving discovery materials due to misaddressed hard drive package.

events.title: Google Alert about Bureau of Prisons
events.description: Google Alert email containing various news snippets including one about Trevor Noah asking Hillary Clinton about Jeffrey Epstein's death.

events.title: Barket Reports on Tartaglione's SHU Conditions
events.description: Bruce Barket emails the MCC detailing ongoing severe conditions in Tartaglione's SHU cell, including a water leak, a dead rodent found in his bed, malfunctioning lights, lack of books/discovery, and unconfirmed threats of harsh sanctions from a guard.

events.title: Discovery Hard Drive Delay Explained
events.description: An Assistant U.S. Attorney explains that a discovery hard drive for Tartaglione was delayed due to a misaddressed package, which had to be rerouted between White Plains and downtown offices.

events.title: Marshals Refuse Transfer Request
events.description: An Assistant U.S. Attorney informs Barket that the U.S. Marshals have refused the defense's request to transfer Tartaglione from the MCC to a facility in Nassau County.

events.title: Attorney Visit Delays and Property Review
events.description: Bruce Barket and Aida Leisenring experience a long delay visiting Tartaglione. The SHU Lieutenant meets with Tartaglione to review his books and personal property.

events.title: Sunday Visit Frustration
events.description: Bruce Barket arrives for a Sunday visit but faces a 35-minute wait outside and only gets 30 minutes with his client due to facility procedures.

events.title: Complaints About Deteriorating Conditions
events.description: Barket reports after a visit that Tartaglione's cell has constant water leaks, a rodent was found in his bed, lights malfunction, and his mental health is rapidly declining. He also reports a guard told Tartaglione he would be denied visits, phone, and commissary for a year.

events.title: BOP Staff Tasked with Investigating Complaints
events.description: The Supervisory Staff Attorney directs various MCC departments (Facilities, Safety, SIS, SHU) to investigate specific complaints: cell leak, pest control, FBI incident report, book swap, lighting, and missing discovery.

events.title: Email Complaint About Tartaglione's Conditions
events.description: Bruce Barket sends a detailed email to MCC staff complaining about severe delays in legal visits, loss of Tartaglione's legal materials, and deplorable SHU conditions including a water leak and dead rodent in his bed.

events.title: Sunday Visit Delay
events.description: Bruce Barket arrives at MCC at 7:56 AM but is not allowed to see his client, Nicholas Tartaglione, until after 9:00 AM, resulting in less than 30 minutes of consultation.

events.title: MCC Staff Response to Complaints
events.description: A Supervisory Staff Attorney at MCC responds to Barket's complaints, outlining steps taken to address visitation delays, book limits, access to legal work, and recreation procedures for Tartaglione.

events.title: Marshal's Refusal of Transfer
events.description: AUSA Jason Swergold informs Bruce Barket that the U.S. Marshals have refused the defense's request to transfer Nicholas Tartaglione to Nassau County.

events.title: Email Complaints About Tartaglione's Conditions
events.description: Bruce Barket sends an email detailing ongoing poor conditions in Tartaglione's SHU cell (leaks, dead rodent, lighting issues), lack of discovery, and reports of harsh punishment from a guard.

events.title: Attorney Visit Delays
events.description: Bruce Barket describes significant delays and obstacles in visiting his client Nicholas Tartaglione at MCC on a Sunday, hindering legal preparation.

events.title: Discovery Delivery Issues
events.description: An Assistant U.S. Attorney explains a delay in Tartaglione receiving a discovery hard drive due to a misaddressed package.

events.title: Request for Psychiatric Evaluation
events.description: A Chief Psychologist at MCC is asked to evaluate Tartaglione for medication due to his reported increased depression and anxiety while in SHU.

events.title: Thursday Visit Delay
events.description: Bruce Barket and Aida Leisenring arrive at MCC at 7:55 AM but are not permitted to see Tartaglione until 9:30 AM, resulting in a very short meeting.

events.title: Hard Drive Delivery Issue
events.description: An AUSA informs Barket that a hard drive containing discovery for Tartaglione was misdelivered within the U.S. Attorney's Office, causing a delay in Tartaglione receiving it.

events.title: Request for Psychiatric Evaluation
events.description: Following a report from Barket about Tartaglione's declining mental health, a BOP supervisory staff attorney forwards a request to the Chief Psychologist to have Tartaglione seen for psychiatric medication.

events.title: Denial of Transfer Request
events.description: An AUSA informs Barket that the U.S. Marshals have refused the defense's request to transfer Tartaglione to a facility in Nassau County.

events.title: Ongoing Visitation and Condition Complaints
events.description: Throughout July 2019, defense attorney Bruce Barket sends multiple emails detailing systemic delays in visiting his client Nick Tartaglione at MCC, loss of the client's legal materials and books, and deplorable cell conditions including water leaks and a dead rodent.

events.title: Border Patrol Agent Rams Migrant
events.description: U.S. Border Patrol Agent Matthew Bowen intentionally rammed his truck into a Guatemalan migrant.

events.title: AP Publishes Domingo Harassment Allegations
events.description: The Associated Press published allegations from eight singers and a dancer accusing opera legend Placido Domingo of sexual harassment and pressuring them into sexual relationships over three decades.

events.title: Trump Administration Weakens Endangered Species Act
events.description: The Trump administration announced final rules to weaken the Endangered Species Act of 1973, reducing habitat protections and removing climate change forecasting tools.

events.title: Scheduled Start of 'Public Charge' Rule
events.description: The Trump administration's new 'public charge' rule, making it harder for legal immigrants who use public benefits to get green cards, is due to take effect.

events.title: Sentencing of Border Patrol Agent Bowen
events.description: Matthew Bowen is scheduled to be sentenced for deprivation of rights under color of law, facing up to one year in prison.

events.title: Guatemala Migration Deal Scheduled
events.description: A U.S.-Guatemala 'safe third country' migration deal signed by the outgoing administration is scheduled to come into effect in mid-August, pending potential opposition from the president-elect.

events.title: Epstein found dead in cell
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein was found hanging in his cell at the Metropolitan Correctional Center in Manhattan.

events.title: Barr comments on Epstein death
events.description: Attorney General Bill Barr publicly criticized the Federal Bureau of Prisons for the 'failure' that led to Epstein's death and stated the investigation into his associates would continue.

events.title: Stevisits Epstein
events.description: James Stewart of The New York Times visited Jeffrey Epstein at his Manhattan mansion, where Epstein claimed to have photos and damaging information on many powerful people.

events.title: Hong Kong airport protests
events.description: Protesters reoccupied Hong Kong International Airport, disrupting flights for a second day during ongoing pro-democracy demonstrations.

events.title: Iowa State Fair campaign events
events.description: Multiple 2020 Democratic presidential candidates, including Bernie Sanders, Amy Klobuchar, and Julian Castro, campaigned at the Iowa State Fair.

events.title: Barr Comments on Epstein Death
events.description: Attorney General Bill Barr publicly criticizes the Bureau of Prisons for the 'failure' to secure Epstein and states the investigation into his associates will continue.

events.title: James Stewart Visits Epstein
events.description: New York Times journalist James Stewart visits Jeffrey Epstein at his Manhattan mansion. Epstein claims to have photos and damaging information on many powerful people.

events.title: Defense Team Call on MCC Conditions
events.description: Epstein's defense attorneys (Ricco, Barket, Leisenring, Bachrach) schedule a call to discuss conditions at the Metropolitan Correctional Center.

events.title: Tartaglione book swap
events.description: Last time Tartaglione had his books swapped out at MCC, reportedly done by someone himself.

events.title: Complaint about MCC conditions
events.description: Bruce Barket emails detailing ongoing problems at MCC including lack of book swaps, missing radio batteries, and intimidating comments from guards.

events.title: Scheduling call about MCC conditions
events.description: Email exchange scheduling a call to discuss MCC conditions issues.

events.title: Request to view Tartaglione's cell
events.description: Bruce Barket requests to view cells and common areas where Tartaglione has been held for penalty phase preparation.

events.title: Follow-up on cell visit request
events.description: Follow-up emails regarding scheduling a site visit to view Tartaglione's confinement areas.

events.title: MCC visit planning
events.description: Email regarding planned MCC visit by U.S. Attorney's Office to see psych observation area, SHU, and Epstein's cell.

events.title: Suicide Watch Logging
events.description: Staff assigned to suicide watch for Epstein used the wrong logbook (VM companion log) instead of the Staff Suicide Watch log; a second corrected log was created.

events.title: Medical Mortality Review Initiated
events.description: Email correspondence begins regarding a medical mortality review for Jeffrey Epstein, Reg. No. 73618-054.

events.title: Psych Reconstruction Response
events.description: Email regarding a psychological reconstruction response for Epstein, with notice of staff being away from the office.

events.title: Epstein placed on suicide watch
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein is placed on suicide watch at the Metropolitan Correctional Center, New York, beginning at 01:40.

events.title: Epstein transferred to psych observation
events.description: Epstein is transferred from suicide watch to psychological observation at 08:45.

events.title: Epstein medically not cleared
events.description: Inmate history report indicates Epstein was 'not medically cleared' starting on this date.

events.title: Suicide watch logs transmitted
events.description: The Associate Warden sends an email with attachments containing the suicide watch chronological logs for July 23-24, 2019.

events.title: Jeffrey Epstein's Apparent Suicide
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein died by apparent suicide at the Manhattan Correctional Center.

events.title: Attorney Request to View Tartaglione Cell
events.description: Bruce Barket emails the U.S. Attorney's Office requesting to view Nicholas Tartaglione's jail cell and common areas at MCC for penalty phase preparation.

events.title: Follow-up on Tartaglione Cell Visit
events.description: Email exchange coordinating schedules to discuss the attorney's request to view Tartaglione's cell.

events.title: Media Inquiry on Video Monitoring
events.description: Email thread regarding a USA Today media inquiry about video monitoring, possibly related to prison operations.

events.title: Prior BOP Response to Washington Post
events.description: The BOP's IPPA leadership finalized a detailed answer about the BOP's Suicide Prevention Program sent to the Washington Post, which is referenced and partially reused in drafting the response to USA Today.

events.title: BOP Response to Washington Post on Suicide Prevention
events.description: The BOP Public Information Office sent a finalized response to the Washington Post about BOP suicide prevention programs, which was later referenced for the USA Today inquiry.

events.title: Chronological Log Submission re: Epstein
events.description: A BOP associate warden at MCC New York submits a chronological log regarding Jeffrey Epstein covering July 23-24, 2019, noting a log-keeping error where the wrong book was used.

events.title: Epstein Suicide Watch Log Error
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein was placed on suicide watch at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC). A staff member was assigned to watch him but used the wrong logbook (Inmate Companions Log) instead of the Staff Suicide Watch Log. The error was later discovered and a correct log was completed.

events.title: Bistrian Case Oral Argument
events.description: Judge Cynthia Rufe held oral argument on a spoliation motion in the Bistrian v. USA case. She stunned attendees by referencing public and Attorney General outrage over Jeffrey Epstein's suicide watch to argue about the importance of preserving evidence like video footage.

events.title: Bistrian Case Chambers Conference
events.description: Judge Rufe met with counsel in chambers, recalling her prior trial of inmate Kareem Milhouse who attacked his attorney with a razor in 2006. She suggested this prior incident was relevant to the Bistrian case and questioned what the Federal Detention Center (FDC) knew about razor threats.

events.title: Scheduled USAO Strategy Meeting
events.description: The U.S. Attorney's Office scheduled a meeting to decide on a tactical response to Judge Rufe's actions in the Bistrian case, including potential written opposition or a motion for recusal.

events.title: USAO Meeting Request
events.description: A meeting with the U.S. Attorney's Office (USAO) was requested for Wednesday, September 4th, 2019, as indicated in the email subject.

keyFacts: Jeffrey Epstein was found unresponsive in his cell at 6:33 am on August 10, 2019, and was pronounced dead at Beekman Hospital at 7:36 am.
Epstein's cellmate, Efrain Reyes, had been released to court the previous day and did not return, leaving Epstein alone in a single cell.

A BOP memorandum dated December 27, 2019, criticizes MCC New York's institutional response, noting a 'local bias' among some staff regarding a prior July 23, 2019 incident involving Epstein and a lack of transparency in executive staff decision-making.

The document reveals systemic issues at MCC New York, including inadequate psychologist input in housing decisions for vulnerable inmates, provision of inaccurate documentation (like an outdated AED list), and insufficient training on sex offender risk factors.
Multiple agencies (FBI, OIG, USMS, AUSA) were notified and involved in the response to Epstein's death on August 10, 2019.
The BOP Reentry Services Division found MCC New York's corrective action plan following Jeffrey Epstein's suicide to be 'unclear or insufficient' in multiple areas.

The feedback memo highlights a 'local bias' among some MCC staff who presumed a July 23, 2019 incident involving Epstein was 'self-directed violence' before the SIS investigation could determine if it was an assault or suicide attempt.
Psychology Services was noted as not being 'adequately represented in the decision making of Executive Staff' regarding housing for vulnerable inmates like Epstein.

Attorney Bruce Barket details systemic problems with attorney-client access at MCC New York, including long delays, broken equipment, and facility closures, hindering the defense of his client Nick Tartaglione.
A Google Alert from August 2019, included in the document, references the removal of the acting director of the BOP following Epstein's death.

Defense attorney Bruce Barket detailed significant obstacles in representing client Nicholas Tartaglione at MCC, including hours-long visitation waits and the client's lack of access to discovery and personal books.
Jeffrey Epstein's attorney, Martin Weinberg, had his credentials verified for visitation at MCC following Epstein's arrest.
A news article included in the correspondence confirms Jeffrey Epstein's suicide at MCC on August 10, 2019, and mentions Attorney General William Barr's comments about staff non-cooperation.
Internal BOP emails show discussions about implementing a "clearinghouse" process for evaluating inmate programs, a priority following testimony by BOP Director Dr. Sawyer.
The document reveals operational challenges within the federal prison system regarding inmate access to legal counsel and materials.
A tour of the MCC's SHU, Jeffrey Epstein's cell, and the suicide watch area was scheduled for August 15, 2019, for high-level DOJ and USAO SDNY officials including Ed O'Callahan and Geoffrey Berman.

The email regarding the tour states the tour would be of Epstein's cell 'to the extent it does not contaminate the crime scene,' indicating it was post-mortem and the cell was treated as a crime scene.

Defense attorney Bruce Barket details severe, systemic obstacles to attorney-client meetings at the MCC, including hours-long delays, broken equipment, and facility closures, hampering the defense of death penalty client Nicholas Tartaglione.

Defense attorney Bruce Barket documents systemic, multi-year problems with attorney-client visits at MCC, including hours-long delays, early closures, and broken equipment in conference rooms.

Tartaglione's detention conditions are described as harsh: constant water leaks in his cell, finding a dead rodent in his bed, lights off during the day, being locked in his cell 24/7 with no recreation, and denial of books and legal discovery.

Barket states that the Bureau of Prisons (BOP) monitors emails and phone calls between lawyers and their clients at MCC, forcing all case discussions to occur in-person during difficult-to-schedule visits.

A guard allegedly told Tartaglione he would be denied visits, phone calls, and commissary for a year in addition to 90 days in SHU, and his mental health is reported to be 'diminishing rapidly' with increased depression and anxiety.
